articles.headline: Google Stock Tops $1,000, Highlighting a Tech Divide
articles.snippet: The shares closed up by a record 14 percent in another reminder that a handful of companies have taken control of the technology industry.
articles.abstract: The shares closed up by a record 14 percent in another reminder that a handful of companies have taken control of the technology industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google has done something few companies ever do in the stock market: it has joined the $1,000 club.

articles.headline: No Ruling in Macy’s v. Penney? Try This
articles.snippet: Macy’s and J.C. Penney await a ruling from a judge in their legal dispute over Martha Stewart merchandise, but the law and facts are clear.
articles.abstract: Macy’s and J.C. Penney await a ruling from a judge in their legal dispute over Martha Stewart merchandise, but the law and facts are clear.
articles.lead_paragraph: The end may be near for the long-running fight between Macy’s and J. C. Penney over Martha Stewart merchandise. Then again, it may not.

articles.headline: California Sees Gridlock Ease in Governing
articles.snippet: New election rules in California, once a symbol of government dysfunction, may be having their desired effect of leaching some of the partisanship out of politics.
articles.abstract: New election rules in California, once a symbol of government dysfunction, may be having their desired effect of leaching some of the partisanship out of politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Before Washington, California was the national symbol of partisan paralysis and government dysfunction.

articles.headline: Case Against Madoff Sons Is Dismissed in London
articles.snippet: A judge, Andrew Popplewell, ruled that Andrew and Mark Madoff and six other associates tied to Bernard L. Madoff were unaware of the Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: A judge, Andrew Popplewell, ruled that Andrew and Mark Madoff and six other associates tied to Bernard L. Madoff were unaware of the Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of the many questions asked about Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, among the most frequent is whether his sons knew about the fraud despite their staunch insistence that they were kept in the dark.

articles.headline: Out of Network, Not by Choice, and Facing Huge Health Bills
articles.snippet: Consumers may face big payments to doctors who participate in their care, in an emergency or in a hospital, but are not in their insurance network.
articles.abstract: Consumers may face big payments to doctors who participate in their care, in an emergency or in a hospital, but are not in their insurance network.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once the cardiologist figured out why Raquel and Michael D’Andrea’s 9-week-old daughter was so frail and unable to eat, he immediately sent her to the hospital for heart surgery.

articles.headline: After Running Hot, Market for Used Cars Is Cooling
articles.snippet: Prices for used cars jumped during the recession, when supply could not meet demand. Now more cars are coming off their leases, and prices are expected to fall.
articles.abstract: Prices for used cars jumped during the recession, when supply could not meet demand. Now more cars are coming off their leases, and prices are expected to fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — It was 9:30 on a recent Tuesday morning at Manheim Riverside, a wholesale auto auction, and more than a thousand used-car dealers were mulling in the desert heat. The bidders had gathered on the perimeters of Manheim’s 10 lanes of cars, watching the vehicles cycle through 10 different auction blocks, at no longer than 45 seconds a pop. Over a collective din that drowns out the auctioneers, the dealers wink, nod or, for the less stealthy, raise a hand to indicate their bid.

articles.headline: Hit by Low Prices, Lobstermen Are at Odds in Maine and Canada
articles.snippet: A surplus of lobster has pushed down prices and stoked arguments over the coast of origin, and even which flag’s catch is the tastiest.
articles.abstract: A surplus of lobster has pushed down prices and stoked arguments over the coast of origin, and even which flag’s catch is the tastiest.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Lobsters do not respect the lines on maps that define the Canada-United States border. They traverse the seabed contentedly munching on herring from New England to Newfoundland.

articles.headline: Corruption in Peru Aids Cutting of Rain Forest
articles.snippet: The World Bank estimates that 80 percent of Peru’s logging exports are illegally harvested, a problem compounded by bribery and obstacles to prosecution.
articles.abstract: The World Bank estimates that 80 percent of Peru’s logging exports are illegally harvested, a problem compounded by bribery and obstacles to prosecution.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUCALLPA, Peru — Afraid the police would tip off suspects, Francisco Berrospi kept local officers in the dark when he headed into the rain forest as a prosecutor to investigate illegal logging. Sometimes it hardly seemed to matter, though.
articles.byline: By William Neuman and Andrea Zarate

articles.headline: States Are Focus of Effort to Foil Health Care Law
articles.snippet: Conservative groups are increasingly taking the fight against President Obama’s health care law to states like Virginia in an effort to block Medicaid expansion.
articles.abstract: Conservative groups are increasingly taking the fight against President Obama’s health care law to states like Virginia in an effort to block Medicaid expansion.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — The federal government is again open for business, and Republicans in Washington are licking their wounds from the failed Tea Party attempt to derail President Obama’s health care overhaul. But here in Virginia’s capital, conservative activists are pursuing a hardball campaign as they chart an alternative path to undoing “Obamacare” — through the states.

articles.headline: Lobbying Bonanza as Firms Try to Influence European Union
articles.snippet: As the European Union has emerged as a regulatory superpower affecting 28 countries, lobbying in its seat of power has become ever more competitive.
articles.abstract: As the European Union has emerged as a regulatory superpower affecting 28 countries, lobbying in its seat of power has become ever more competitive.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — It was a show of force in keeping with the ambitions of American law firms that increasingly see the European Union’s vast apparatus as a vital lobbying opportunity for themselves and their multinational corporate clients.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: How to Pay Millions and Lag Behind the Market
articles.snippet: Rhode Island’s pension investments in hedge funds have trailed returns earned by the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index and have cost the state $70 million in fees in a single year.
articles.abstract: Rhode Island’s pension investments in hedge funds have trailed returns earned by the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index and have cost the state $70 million in fees in a single year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Today’s low-interest-rate environment has made the hunt for investment income tougher than ever. Many overseers of public pension funds, desperate to bolster returns and meet ballooning retiree obligations, have turned from traditional investments like stocks and bonds to hedge funds and private equity.

articles.headline: Tentative Deal Hands JPMorgan Chase a Record Penalty
articles.snippet: The penalty would cap weeks of heated negotiating and underscore the extent of the bank’s legal woes, people briefed on the talks said.
articles.abstract: The penalty would cap weeks of heated negotiating and underscore the extent of the bank’s legal woes, people briefed on the talks said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:06 p.m. |
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: A Boy Who Played With Trains
articles.snippet: For the novelist Richard Ford, an early job in an Arkansas rail yard taught valuable lessons about the working world’s challenges and foibles.
articles.abstract: For the novelist Richard Ford, an early job in an Arkansas rail yard taught valuable lessons about the working world’s challenges and foibles.
articles.lead_paragraph: My first job that mattered was on the Missouri Pacific Railroad, in 1963. I hired out — railroad lingo — as a locomotive fireman, working the switchyards in Little Rock, Ark. I was 19, and knew almost nothing about anything — certainly not about real work, and not about how work almost always affiliates you significantly with the lives of others.

articles.headline: This Is War (for a Game Industry’s Soul)
articles.snippet: With “Battlefield 4,” a Swedish team is trying to make an even more vivid military shooter video game. The genre is under siege from the rising popularity of smartphone games.
articles.abstract: With “Battlefield 4,” a Swedish team is trying to make an even more vivid military shooter video game. The genre is under siege from the rising popularity of smartphone games.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Swedish Army drafted Patrick Bach in the early 1990s and tried to make a soldier out of him. No such luck. Mr. Bach couldn’t see the point of pretending to protect a country at peace since the Napoleonic wars. The only part he liked was the shooting.

articles.headline: To Catch Up, Walmart Moves to Amazon Turf
articles.snippet: Walmart is beefing up its technology in an effort to compete with Amazon for Internet shoppers and the software engineers needed to attract them.
articles.abstract: Walmart is beefing up its technology in an effort to compete with Amazon for Internet shoppers and the software engineers needed to attract them.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN BRUNO, Calif. — A plucky Silicon Valley company, forced to compete for talented engineers, is trying it all — recruiting billboards on Highway 101; workplace perks like treadmill workstations and foosball tables; and conference rooms named after celebrities like Rihanna and Justin Bieber.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: Authors Accept Censors’ Rules to Sell in China
articles.snippet: Western writers often face a difficult choice: accept a censor’s heavy hand or bypass the world’s biggest market.
articles.abstract: Western writers often face a difficult choice: accept a censor’s heavy hand or bypass the world’s biggest market.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese readers of Ezra F. Vogel’s sprawling biography of China’s reformist leader Deng Xiaoping may have missed a few details that appeared in the original English edition.

articles.headline: Lobbyists Ready for a New Fight on U.S. Spending
articles.snippet: Those representing special interest groups, including retirees and defense contractors, are gearing up to ensure that their constituents are spared cuts in new budget negotiations.
articles.abstract: Those representing special interest groups, including retirees and defense contractors, are gearing up to ensure that their constituents are spared cuts in new budget negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Throughout the tense fiscal deadlock in recent weeks, some of the most powerful forces in Washington, including retirees and defense contractors, largely sat on the sidelines. Now they are preparing for a political fight with billions of federal dollars at stake.

articles.headline: Fiscal Crisis Sounds the Charge in G.O.P.’s ‘Civil War’
articles.snippet: The confrontation between Tea Party conservatives and establishment Republicans will play out in the coming Congressional and presidential primaries in 2014 and 2016.
articles.abstract: The confrontation between Tea Party conservatives and establishment Republicans will play out in the coming Congressional and presidential primaries in 2014 and 2016.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the budget standoff ended in crushing defeat last week and the political damage reports began to pile up for Republicans, one longtime party leader after another stepped forward to chastise their less seasoned, Tea Party-inspired colleagues who drove the losing strategy.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin, Jim Rutenberg and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: The Man Who’ll Do Triage on Europe’s Banks
articles.snippet: Ignazio Angeloni, a top European Central Bank official, has a leading role in reviewing euro zone banks to determine which are sound and which are not.
articles.abstract: Ignazio Angeloni, a top European Central Bank official, has a leading role in reviewing euro zone banks to determine which are sound and which are not.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — All Ignazio Angeloni has to do is figure out Europe’s banking system.

articles.headline: Spinning Horror Into Gold
articles.snippet: The producer Jason Blum’s winning movie formula relies on profit-sharing, and he’s thinking about applying it to television.
articles.abstract: The producer Jason Blum’s winning movie formula relies on profit-sharing, and he’s thinking about applying it to television.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At first glance, there is nothing particularly special about Jason Blum. He makes low-cost horror films that sell a lot of tickets. Producers have been getting rich from that formula for decades: rinse (the fake blood) and repeat.

articles.headline: Tablet Makers Gear Up for Latest Skirmish
articles.snippet: The intense competition in the market for tablets will be highlighted on Tuesday, as Apple, Nokia and Microsoft each introduce new devices.
articles.abstract: The intense competition in the market for tablets will be highlighted on Tuesday, as Apple, Nokia and Microsoft each introduce new devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The race for the tablet market has become a full-blown sprint.

articles.headline: Tech Wealth and Ideas Are Heading Into News
articles.snippet: The technology industry and its various power brokers are suddenly investing significant sums of money in preserving news capacity and quality.
articles.abstract: The technology industry and its various power brokers are suddenly investing significant sums of money in preserving news capacity and quality.
articles.lead_paragraph: Producing serious news is an expensive enterprise with a beleaguered business model, one that remains tied to the tracks as a locomotive of splintered audiences and declining advertising hurtles toward it.

articles.headline: China’s Arms Industry Makes Global Inroads
articles.snippet: From drones to frigates to fighter jets, Chinese companies are aggressively pushing sales of high-tech hardware, mostly in the developing world.
articles.abstract: From drones to frigates to fighter jets, Chinese companies are aggressively pushing sales of high-tech hardware, mostly in the developing world.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — From the moment Turkey announced plans two years ago to acquire a long-range missile defense system, the multibillion-dollar contract from a key NATO member appeared to be an American company’s to lose.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Nicola Clark

articles.headline: Despite Legal Tempests, Dimon Appears Solid as Ever Atop JPMorgan
articles.snippet: Mounting legal problems have so far left Jamie Dimon unscathed at the helm of JPMorgan Chase.
articles.abstract: Mounting legal problems have so far left Jamie Dimon unscathed at the helm of JPMorgan Chase.
articles.lead_paragraph: To Wall Street, Jamie Dimon looks like the Teflon C.E.O.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Contractors See Weeks of Work on Health Site
articles.snippet: Experts involved in fixing the online health insurance marketplace say the technological problems are extensive.
articles.abstract: Experts involved in fixing the online health insurance marketplace say the technological problems are extensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal contractors have identified most of the main problems crippling President Obama’s online health insurance marketplace, but the administration has been slow to issue orders for fixing those flaws, and some contractors worry that the system may be weeks away from operating smoothly, people close to the project say.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Ian Austen and Robert Pear

articles.headline: U.S. Deal With JPMorgan Followed a Crucial Call
articles.snippet: A tentative $13 billion settlement between JPMorgan and the Justice Department was a result of extensive personal negotiations involving Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chief executive, and Attorney General Eric Holder.
articles.abstract: A tentative $13 billion settlement between JPMorgan and the Justice Department was a result of extensive personal negotiations involving Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chief executive, and Attorney General Eric Holder.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a museum on Fifth Avenue, in a sparkling reception hall overlooking Central Park, Jamie Dimon convened his top executives and their spouses last month for the Wall Street equivalent of a pep rally.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
